project.teaser: Restoring Ecosystems to Stop the Threat Of (Re-)Emerging Infectious Diseases: There is a growing body of evidence that landscape degradation is linked to zoonotic spillover risk. Large scale restoration is increasingly being touted as an effective solution for mitigating...
project.objective: Restoring Ecosystems to Stop the Threat Of (Re-)Emerging Infectious Diseases: There is a growing body of evidence that landscape degradation is linked to zoonotic spillover risk. Large scale restoration is increasingly being touted as an effective solution for mitigating against a range of anthropogenic impacts and is also hypothesised to protect against zoonotic disease spillover. However, little is known about the mechanisms with which restoration may provide this protection. It is commonly assumed that restoration mirrors in reverse the processes that occur during degradation; however, it is likely that this relationship is in fact asymmetric. Rarely can restored landscapes be returned to a state similar to that of pristine ecosystems, and often restored landscapes need to fulfil a range of environmental and socioeconomic requirements that inherently prevent them from doing so. Additionally, the spatiotemporal scale necessary to effect positive change is context dependent, and the type of restoration necessary to protect against zoonotic spillover is currently unknown. Ecosystem restoration can vary widely in type, scale and context and can also change how humans interact with their environment, which may have unexpected consequences for zoonotic disease spillover. Given the complexity of these interactions and their effect on disease, it is vital that we understand how restoration specifically might impact wildlife disease and emergent spillover risk.
project.title: Restoring Ecosystems to Stop the Threat Of Re - Emerging Infectious Disease

article.title: Analysing ecosystem restoration to minimise zoonotic spillover risk

result.title: Project Handbook
result.description: D71.1 Project Handbook – All guidance and procedures for project and consortium management including internal communication, decision-making and reporting procedures. (Task 7.1)

result.title: Knowledge Exchange Platform (KEP)
result.description: D6.2 Joint deliverable with the sister project ZOE - an integrative knowledge exchange platform hosted by the Open Science Framework - supporting knowledge gathering and exchange

result.title: Game release
result.description: D1.5 Release of Restore-IT! game to the public on mobile app stores (e.g., Google Play) and advertise it (Task 1.5). Release will be advertised among key different groups to encourage uptake among diverse user groups.

result.title: Game testing
result.description: D1.4 Report from workshops testing and refining the game with case study stakeholders (Task 1.5). Testing will include game uptake among different stakeholder groups and effectiveness of game at communicating key components of restoration and disease spillover interactions

result.title: Study protocol, collection tools
result.description: D4.1 Research protocol including tools for data collection (SOPs, questionnaires), informed consent forms, information sheets etc needed for ethics application (Task 4.1) for socio-economic studies.

result.title: Data Management Plan
result.description: D7.2 Data Management Plan – Strategy and action plan on research data and output management (UANTWERPEN) (Task 7.2)

result.title: DEC plan
result.description: D6.1 The aim of this deliverable is to report on the planned dissemination and exploitation strategy including communication activities and share and action plan for the dissemination and exploitation activities of the project results (Task 6.4)

result.title: Acoustic sampling protocol
result.description: D2.1 Standardised protocol for edge computing based acoustic sampling for biodiversity (Task 2.1). Protocol will include detailed description on how to design, set up and analyse soundscape study across different restoration contexts to produce soundscape analyses.

result.title: Integrating environment into One Health approaches: Embracing the complexity

details.authors: Christina Lynggaard, Jan F. Gogarten, Pikka Jokelainen

result.title: Literature review
result.description: D1.1 Literature review on the links between restoration, biodiversity, disease risks and One Health (Task 1.1). Review will identify current state of knowledge about how restoration relates to disease spillover risk and knowledge gaps

result.title: Fly sampling protocol
result.description: D2.2 Standardised protocol for carrion fly sampling for iDNA vertebrate diversity assessment (Task 2.1). Protocol will include how to design, sample and analyse carrion fly data to characterise vertebrate diversity in a standardised format across a range of different restoration contexts.

result.title: Policy review
result.description: D1.2 Review of EU policies related to restoration, biodiversity, ecosystem services and the links with One Health (Task 1.2). Review will identify current policies related to restoration and disease spillover effects, and identify areas where more knowledge is needed to guide policy

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
